image.altText: Mitch Marsh and Pat Cummins complete a high five in celebration of a wicket

items.synopsis: Mitch Marsh's blistering 118 saves some respectability for Australia, who is bowled out for 263 by England on day one of third Ashes Test at Headingley. Follow all the action in our live blog.

title.children: Cummins claims early wickets after England rolls Australia despite Marsh ton

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: And it's a brilliant catch from Carey! Full stretch to his left. Incredible catch. Australia gets an early wicket that they sorely needed, Duckett goes for 2 off 6! Headingley is very quiet all of a sudden. Carey actually used his mouth to finish off that catch. Sealed with a kiss. And why not.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: EDGED! TAKEN! DUCKETT GOES!

children.content: And it's a brilliant catch from Carey! Full stretch to his left.
(Getty Images)
Incredible catch.
Australia gets an early wicket that they sorely needed, Duckett goes for 2 off 6!
(Getty Images)
Headingley is very quiet all of a sudden.
Carey actually used his mouth to finish off that catch. Sealed with a kiss. And why not.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: What a day for returning weapons. Todd Murphy chops on to give him his fifth in his first Test since December, just wreaking havoc with legitimate pace but also, pivotally, accuracy, control and swing. He got Usman Khawaja with the ball of the innings, then mopped up at the end with Carey, Starc, Cummins and Murphy all falling victim to his wily ways. Wood finished with 5-34 from 11.4 overs. On the other side, almost everyone struggled against a properly impressive bowling effort, where all the seamers were on song and found movement off the pitch and through the air. It was only the recalled Mitch Marsh who shone, with his 118 off 118 containing some of the most powerful striking we've seen in, well, about four days, since Ben Stokes rocked Lord's. But I think this was even better from a pure striking perspective. That knock saved Australia from total disaster, but it's not a big total because Travis Head was the only other Aussie who got more than 22. So the Australian bowlers still have to follow that up with a brilliant start against the English top order.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australia is all out for 263 and Mark Wood has five wickets!

children.content: What a day for returning weapons.
Todd Murphy chops on to give him his fifth in his first Test since December, just wreaking havoc with legitimate pace but also, pivotally, accuracy, control and swing.

props.alt: England bowler Mark Wood holds up a cricket ball as he walks off the field.

children.content: (Getty)
He got Usman Khawaja with the ball of the innings, then mopped up at the end with Carey, Starc, Cummins and Murphy all falling victim to his wily ways. Wood finished with 5-34 from 11.4 overs.
On the other side, almost everyone struggled against a properly impressive bowling effort, where all the seamers were on song and found movement off the pitch and through the air.

It was only the recalled Mitch Marsh who shone, with his 118 off 118 containing some of the most powerful striking we've seen in, well, about four days, since Ben Stokes rocked Lord's. But I think this was even better from a pure striking perspective.

props.alt: Mitch Marsh completes a swing of the bat.

children.content: (Getty)

That knock saved Australia from total disaster, but it's not a big total because Travis Head was the only other Aussie who got more than 22. So the Australian bowlers still have to follow that up with a brilliant start against the English top order.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Marsh inside edges onto his back thigh pad and he goes for 118 off 118, taking us to tea. England was asking the question, and Marsh just walked. Class. What a knock though, in his first Test in four years, and five-and-a-half years since his last century, also in the Ashes back in the last game of the 2017/18 series. He took Australia from 4-85 to 4-240 before finally falling to Chris Woakes, who's still finding swing. Meanwhile, Travis Head is still unbeaten on 39 off 67. Alex Carey will join him at the crease after tea, so there's plenty of fight left.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Mitch Marsh finally falls, and that's tea!

props.alt: Mitch Marsh screams as he hugs Travis Head.

children.content: (Getty)
Marsh inside edges onto his back thigh pad and he goes for 118 off 118, taking us to tea.
England was asking the question, and Marsh just walked. Class.
What a knock though, in his first Test in four years, and five-and-a-half years since his last century, also in the Ashes back in the last game of the 2017/18 series.
He took Australia from 4-85 to 4-240 before finally falling to Chris Woakes, who's still finding swing.
Meanwhile, Travis Head is still unbeaten on 39 off 67. Alex Carey will join him at the crease after tea, so there's plenty of fight left.

image.altText: A woman stands in a white dress in the rain.

items.synopsis: Former Canberra political staffer Brittany Higgins says she has received a "concerns notice" from WA senator Linda Reynolds threatening legal action, with the senator declaring she "will not tolerate being defamed".

title.children: Brittany Higgins says WA senator Linda Reynolds has threatened to sue her over Instagram post

image.altText: Forensic police offices put items into an evidence bag.

items.synopsis: WA Police investigate the death of a man at a service station in Perth's north, searching several properties as part of their enquires.

title.children: Police searching several properties after man dies in suspected stabbing at Perth service station

image.altText: Founder of Wagner private mercenary group Yevgeny Prigozhin in military gear.

items.synopsis: Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko, who last month brokered a deal to end an armed mutiny in Russia, says Russian mercenary leader Yevgeny Prigozhin is no longer in Belarus.

title.children: Yevgeny Prigozhin is not in Belarus, Lukashenko says, as Russian state TV airs footage of Wagner leader's palace

image.altText: Emily Woods stands alongside her husband's casket with her head down.

items.synopsis: A police officer is remembered for his "kind and caring" nature as hundreds gather to pay their respects to the young constable after he was killed in the line of duty.

title.children: 'I am so proud of you': Wife delivers heartfelt tribute as hundreds farewell WA police officer

image.altText: Tony Abbott sits in a chair with his hands in his lap.

items.synopsis: Former prime minister Tony Abbott says a constitutionally enshrined Voice to Parliament is "wrong in principle" and will reinforce "separatism" in Australia.

title.children: Voice to Parliament 'damaging in the long term', former PM Tony Abbott says

image.altText: A composite image showing a middle-aged man with an odd expression and a middle-aged woman.

items.synopsis: The younger Trump, who had been booked on a three-day tour that was scheduled to begin in Sydney on Sunday, cancelled the trip on Wednesday, with organisers suggesting the reason was visa issues. Ms O'Neil says that wasn't the case.

title.children: Home Affairs Minister Clare O'Neil calls Donald Trump Jr a 'big baby' over cancelled Australian speaking tour

image.altText: A young girl with red hair tucked into bed, lying on her side and blowing her nose.

items.synopsis: The number of respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) cases have jumped close to 10 times higher in some states across Australia when compared to last year. Experts say COVID complacency and higher testing rates could be why.

title.children: RSV cases skyrocket across the country compared to same time last year

image.altText: A cartoon advertisment in the australian financial review newspaper depicting Kate Chaney, her father and Thomas Mayo

items.synopsis: Media company Nine has apologised for an ad that has been condemned as "racist" for its depiction of a Torres Strait Islander man, insisting it should have never been published in one of its papers.

title.children: Nine apologises for 'racist' anti-Voice ad, says it shouldn't have been published

image.altText: A close-up shot of the District Court of WA in Perth, showing signage on the building's front facade with the court's name.

items.synopsis: The sanity of a man who allegedly broke into the home of a seven year-old girl, choked and sexually assaulted her in her bed in the early hours of the morning will be an issue at his trial, the Perth District Court hears.

title.children: 'Sanity' an issue in trial of Perth man who allegedly broke into child's bedroom and sexually assaulted her

image.altText: Australian cyclist Jai Hindley looks in the camera with a beaming smile after winning a Tour de France stage.

items.synopsis: Jai Hindley did his homework ahead of the Tour de France, and it pays off with an opportunistic breakaway on day one in the Pyrenees — now the Perth rider is living his cycling dream with his parents there to witness it, writes Sophie Smith.

title.children: 'Living like a monk' pays off for West Aussie Jai Hindley, as his perfect Tour prep is capped by mountain breakaway

image.altText: A woman dances with four children wearing orange and traditional skirts.

items.synopsis: Four traditional owner groups have celebrated in Cairns after their land in Cape York was formally recognised.

title.children: Native title recognised for 850,000ha of Far North Queensland

image.altText: Remote highway in outback Australia

items.synopsis: Two Queensland men who were arrested on the Nullarbor with 70 kilograms of cocaine allegedly being towed in a trailer have been granted bail, despite WA Police raising concerns about them being a flight risk.

title.children: Queensland men caught on alleged cross-Nullarbor drug run face court

image.altText: Bystanders react to a large fire

items.synopsis: Since Saturday, Australians have been required to wait until the age of 67 until they can get the age pension. It has happened with little protest — a stark contrast to the demonstrations and riots that have rocked France, writes Peter Whiteford.

title.children: Our retirement age just went up — so why aren't we as angry as the French?

image.altText: A composite picture of two women sitting with contemplative expressions.

items.synopsis: A Noongar elder and advocates from both sides of the Indigenous Voice to Parliament debate fear many Australians will vote in the looming referendum without knowing what they are voting for.

title.children: These advocates are voting differently on the Voice — they want you to know why

items.synopsis: A Gold Coast dad says his sons are beside themselves as a result of the "disgusting" crime. The family's car was also stolen and their house was trashed.

title.children: Bowie the blind dog, stolen from Gold Coast home, caught on camera at interstate servo

image.altText: Just Stop Oil Wimbledon protest

items.synopsis: Three protesters ran on to one of the world's biggest sporting events, spreading puzzle pieces and confetti in their wake. Here's what we know about them.

title.children: Protesting for their grandchildren's future: the activists who stormed Wimbledon court

image.altText: Toby Nankervis

items.synopsis: Toby Nankervis faces suspension for a high hit on Jake Lloyd, as Richmond keeps its finals hopes alive after a last minute burst.

title.children: Richmond star set for stint on the sidelines as Tigers defeat Swans to keep finals hopes alive

image.altText: A man leaps over another man to score a try.

items.synopsis: Cronulla keeps its spot in the top four safe for now after a second half burst that saw them burn off the struggling Wests Tigers.

title.children: Flurry of tries after debatable bunker call sees Sharks overcome Tigers to keep top four spot safe

image.altText: people sitting insite red floating tubes on top of the brown water

items.synopsis: Data from the University of Maine's Climate Reanalyzer tool, that uses satellite data and computer simulations, showed the earth's average temperature reached 17.18 degrees Celsius on Wednesday.

title.children: For the third day in a row the unofficial record for the global average temperature has been set

image.altText: A man with grey hair wearing a black suit and purple tie.

items.synopsis: Sixteen years after the death of Joanne Howell, Paul Charlton has been found guilty of murdering his ex-partner, leaving her lifeless and battered body at the bottom of the staircase of her Melbourne home in 2007.

title.children: Killer collapses in court after being found guilty of murdering his partner 16 years ago

image.altText: The Cheesecake Shop Salisbury franchise

items.synopsis: The Cheesecake Shop is one of the country’s most well-known cake bakeries. But now four former workers from one store have alleged they were underpaid more than a million dollars.

title.children: Migrant says dreams of Australian residency soured by Cheesecake Shop franchisee

image.altText: A black and white image of an older man with white hair holding a cigarette in his artist studio

items.synopsis: Post MeToo, audiences are reconsidering great artistic works in the light of their creators' transgressions. But is it truly possible to separate the art from the artist?

title.children: Picasso and Polanski committed horrific acts. What do we do with their art?

image.altText: woman taking a selfie in a car

items.synopsis: Ahmad Hodroj is accused of murdering his estranged wife Amira Moughnieh after she died at a home in Sydney's south on Wednesday night.

title.children: 'Loved life': Sydney mother of three allegedly murdered by estranged husband

image.altText: Mostafa ‘Moz’ Azimitabar looks grave

items.synopsis: A Federal Court judge rules the detainment of a Kurdish-Iranian refugee in hotel rooms for more than a year without access to sunshine lawful but lacking "care and humanity".

title.children: Detainment of refugee in hotel for 14 months without fresh air is lawful, court finds

image.altText: Paul Smith in his 20s on a motorbike

items.synopsis: Lightning strikes in a split second. Those who survive being struck can be left with lifelong consequences, including cognitive disability, relationship breakdowns and a dark shadow over their mental health.

title.children: Paul was struck by lightning in his 20s. He was never the same again

image.altText: Firefighters stand on the street as orange flames engulf a building on a boarded-up site.

items.synopsis: Victoria Police says a major fire that erupted at a derelict building site in the centre of Melbourne is being treated as suspicious, as authorities investigate the cause of the blaze.

title.children: Police say major blaze at derelict Melbourne building site suspicious

image.altText: Man's hands holds a handful of rusted metal coins, bracelets, watch, ring, under a blue sky, green trees, beach in distance.

items.synopsis: Memphis, who lives with autism, gets upset when other kids "see that he is different". Now his dad, Jason Marshall, has introduced him to a new pastime, "popular in Europe".

title.children: What is magnet fishing? Treasure hunters say it's an activity that's taking off especially for kids

image.altText: A Chinese woman with long hair smiling and gesturing in geometric black and silver dress on red carpet.

items.synopsis: The Hong Kong-born star had been suffering from depression for several years, her sisters said, with her condition deteriorating drastically over the last few months.

title.children: Pop singer CoCo Lee, who voiced Disney's Mulan, dies at 48

image.altText: A lady with a gold wig and black sequin dress swings her arms dancing the nutbush.

items.synopsis: Almost 6,000 people didn't just break the world record, they blew it away in a colourful, spirited, boot-scooting celebration of the late queen of rock and 50 years of Nutbush City Limits.

title.children: Oh, Nutbush! Thousands stomp to world record as spirit of Tina Turner rocks Birdsville's Big Red Bash
